docs.lead_paragraph: Foot ulcers can be the bane of diabetics, in many cases forcing doctors to amputate a lower limb to prevent further damage. To combat this, diabetics with such problems are routinely counseled to wear therapeutic footwear, and insurance companies and Medicare regularly cover much of the cost.
docs.abstract: Study led by Department of Veterans Affairs researcher Gayle Reiber concludes that use of therapeutic footwear does not help reduce recurrence of foot ulcers in diabetics; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The MIM Corporation, which manages prescription drug benefits for insurance companies and health care providers, yesterday raised its profit forecast for this year, citing a better tax rate and improvements in operations. MIM said it expected profit of 90 cents a share, up from an earlier estimate of 86 cents before a 3-cent gain reported in the first quarter. The company, which is based in Elmsford, N.Y., said it expected sales of $620 million this year, a 36 percent increase from $456.7 million in 2001. MIM's stock rose $2.58, or 26 percent, to $12.46 a share.

headline.main: PRESCRIPTION MANAGER RAISES PROFIT FORECAST FOR YEAR

docs.abstract: MIM Corp, which manages prescription drug benefits for insurance companies and health care providers, raises its profit forecast for year; expects sales of $620 million this year, 36 percent increase from $456.7 million in 2001 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The New York State Legislature's adoption of a bill covering infertility treatments (news article, May 17) recognizes that when a woman has medical difficulties in bearing a child, the costs to correct this condition should be borne by insurance companies. This important measure will help thousands of women who confront medical problems when trying to get pregnant. But unless Albany acts on a bill requiring insurers to cover birth control, millions of women will continue to pay out-of-pocket for contraceptives.
docs.abstract: Kellli Conlin letter, commenting on May 17 article, says New York State Legislature's adoption of bill covering infertility treatments recognizes that when women have difficulty bearing children, costs to correct condition should be borne by insurance companies

docs.lead_paragraph: Like many people taking drugs to combat H.I.V., Steven Hodges, a former hairdresser here, noticed a few years ago that he was becoming gaunt and hollow-cheeked even though he still felt healthy. ''I didn't feel sick, and I didn't want to look sick,'' he said. ''But all my clients kept saying, 'Are you O.K.?' -- which doesn't make you feel any better.''

headline.main: H.I.V. Patients Try to Remedy Gaunt Appearance

docs.abstract: Article on treatments being offered to HIV and AIDS patients to ease lipodystrophy, disruption of body's methods of processing and distributing fat that results in loss of fat on face and accumulation of fatty tissue on shoulders and around neck and belly; corrective procedures, including liposuction and plastic surgery, are not cheap and insurance companies generally refuse to cover costs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board, rejecting calls for the first rent rollback on rent-stabilized apartments, last night recommended increases of 2 percent on one-year leases and 4 percent on two-year leases. The increases, which would apply to leases that are renewed between Oct. 1, 2002, and Sept. 30, 2003, would be equal to the lowest allowed in the last three decades for the city's 2.3 million tenants in rent-stabilized apartments. Such increases were approved five times in the 1990's.

headline.main: City Board Recommends Rent Increases Of 2% and 4%

docs.abstract: New York City Rent Guidelines Board rejects calls for first rent rollback on rent-stabilized apartments and recommends increases of 2 percent on one-year leases and 4 percent on two-year leases; increases would be equal to lowest allowed in last three decades for city's 2.3 million tenants in rent-stabilized apartments; such increases were approved five times in 1990's; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To this quaint Missouri River town named for Daniel Boone's discovery of a salt lick nearby, the new Isle of Capri casino's promise is more than 800 jobs and $4.5 million in annual tax revenue for City Hall. It is seen as the long-sought catalyst that could turn an anonymous community into a regional destination. Already, a Holiday Inn Express has opened near the Interstate, and half a dozen new restaurants are sprouting amid the spruced-up store fronts of Main Street. With an $800,000 donation from the casino, the Friends of Historic Boonville are renovating Thespian Hall, the oldest continuously operating theater west of the Mississippi. A display at the entrance of the turquoise-and-peach gambling palace points visitors toward the Katy Trail, a 19th-century railroad now popular for hiking and biking.

headline.main: Midwest Towns Feel Gambling Is a Sure Thing

docs.abstract: Economy of Midwest is shifting away from long dependence on dying industries and is in midst of casino boom as it relies increasingly on tourism and entertainment; as manufacturing and agriculture have sagged, rural areas and cities have turned to service sector to create jobs and generate economic activity; casinos, which locate where factories will not and succeed where malls and multiplexes cannot, are among most reliable engines of change, whose revenues are causing cultural renaissance that is drawing thousands to unlikely places; six states are currently home to 86 commercial casinos and 87 American Indian operations; chart; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Bermuda Tax Triangle'' (editorial, May 13): You question what I was thinking with our proposal to reincorporate in Bermuda. Reincorporation will allow us to compete with foreign companies on a level playing field. Keeping our company competitive preserves thousands of United States jobs and creates new ones.

headline.main: Why a Tool Maker Relocates Offshore

docs.abstract: Topics of The Times editorial says Bush administration is proposing to allow doctors, hospitals, pharmacists and other health care providers to disclose patient information to one another for treatment, payment of claims or certain business operations, without obtaining consent; says written permission would be required before disclosing information to insurers, employers and marketing firms; says this seems like reasonable approach

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST month, J. Craig Venter, the former president and founder of Celera Genomics, caused a stir in scientific circles by revealing that he had used his own DNA in the company's successful effort to unravel the human genome. The DNA was supposed to have come exclusively from anonymous donors. But protocol aside, it is easy to understand why Mr. Venter might have made himself a guinea pig: Your genetic code offers important clues to your future health and well-being. Researchers have already identified genetic links to thousands of diseases like breast and colon cancer, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes and heart disease. They have more than 900 tests available, including multiple tests for some diseases.

headline.main: Genetic Tests Abound. Why Won't Insurers Pay?

docs.abstract: Michelle Andrews article on reluctance of health insurers to pay for genetic tests to uncover predisposition to diseases; reluctance is greatest when disease is caused by mutations in more than one gene or affected by environmental factors, particularly when no treatment is currently available; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INVESTORS in the gambling industry may have already scored the easy money. Share prices have climbed 94 percent from their September lows, according to the Dow Jones casinos index, and the stocks of the largest casino operators are considerably more expensive than they were before Sept. 11, said Robin Farley, an industry analyst at UBS Warburg. Late last summer, the four largest casino operators traded at an average of 6.6 times Ms. Farley's estimate for 2002 cash flow. Now they are trading at 7.8 times expected 2003 cash flow. ''Not only are they trading at a higher multiple, but we are looking farther ahead,'' she said.

headline.main: Casino Stocks: First, Check the Map

docs.abstract: Outlook for investing in gambling industry stocks, which have climbed 94 percent from their Sept lows, discussed; some investors say better bargains may be found in gambling companies that operate outside Las Vegas; market premium on Las Vegas-focused operators could evaporate if labor problems are not resolved; graph of casino stock performance; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna promoted the head of its health insurance business to president of the company yesterday. In addition to leading the health insurance business, the executive, Ronald A. Williams, will lead Aetna's group insurance, large-case pension and national medical services businesses. Mr. Williams took over the health business in March 2001.

headline.main: AETNA PROMOTES HEALTH INSURANCE CHIEF TO PRESIDENT
